Folder.Title: Programmers Guide
Folder.Description:
This section includes the examples related to following topics:
- Working with Projects - Working with Calendars - Working with Calendar Exceptions - Working with Tasks - Working with Task Links - Working with Task Baselines - Working with Resources - Working with Resource Assignments - Working with Currencies - Miscellaneous

Folder.Title: Working with Projects
Folder.Description:
This section includes the examples related to following topics:
- Creating an Empty Project File - Reading a Project File - Determining Project Version - General Project Properties - Default Project Properties - Writing MPP Project Summary Information - Fiscal Year Properties - Weekday Properties - Currency Properties - Retrieving Calendar Information - Setting Attributes for New Tasks - Retrieving Task Information - Adding and Removing Tasks - Writing Tasks to Project - Retrieving Task Links - Adding and Removing Task Links - Defining Root Task - Retrieving Resource Information - Adding and Removing Resources - Writing Resources to Project - Retrieving Resource Assignment Information - Adding and Removing Resource Assignments - Writing Resource Assignments to Project - Performing Recalculations - Verifying Project Structure - Remove Methods - GetObjectByField Methods - Replacing a Calendar - Extended Attributes - Calculate Critical Path - Recaclulating Project Data - Printing the TaskWritingException - Microsoft Project 2010 MPP File Update - Writing Updated Extended Attribute Definitions and Values to MPP - Saving a Project as PDF - Get Number of Pages in Project - Retrieving Outline Codes

Example.Title: Creating an Empty Project File
Example.Description: Aspose.Tasks can open existing files, but it can also create new files. This example explains how to create a new and empty project file from stream or using the ProjectWriter class.

Example.Title: Setting Attributes for New Tasks
Example.Description: With ASpose.Tasks, it is easy to add tasks to projects. This example explains how to add task and set the default start date for new tasks.

Example.Title: Adding and Removing Tasks
Example.Description: Projects are made up by a series of tasks with resources (staff or equipment) assigned to them. Aspose.Tasks lets you work with tasks in many different ways. A lot of the time, when you're creating a project, you'll want to add tasks. This example explains how to add and remove tasks from a project.

Example.Title: Determining Project Version
Example.Description: Aspose.Tasks lets you retrieve project file information such as the version of Microsoft Project that the file was created with. This example shows how.

Example.Title: Default Project Properties
Example.Description: Microsoft Project lets users set default project properties that speed up the process of setting up a project. The default properties define when a new task starts and finishes, sets the default overtime and standard pay rates and more. Aspose.Tasks supports these features. This example explains both how to read default properties and how to write default properties to a project file.

Example.Title: Writing MPP Project Summary Information
Example.Description: Most programs save summary information with the files they save. Microsoft Project is no different. As well as the name of the author, the date the project was created and the last time it was edited and saved, it saves keywords, subject, comments and more. Aspose.Tasks lets you both read and write this type of information. This example explains how to open a project file, set the summary information and save it again.

Example.Title: Fiscal Year Properties
Example.Description: The fiscal year is the same as a financial year, or budget year. It is the dates between which an country, an organization or an individual calculates budgets and taxes. Microsoft Project lets users define a fiscal year for projects. Aspose.Tasks supports this functionality with properties that allow developers to both read fiscal year properties from existing projects, and set fiscal year properties when creating or working with projects.

Example.Title: Weekday Properties
Example.Description: Microsoft Project lets users set a number of different weekday properties, for example what day a week starts on and how many working days are in a month. Aspose.Tasks support these features through a number of properties that can be used both to read weekday properties and to write them to a project.

Example.Title: Reading Project Files
Example.Description: The Read method exposed by the ProjectReader class is used to read project files. The Read method accepts a valid FileStream object in MPP or XML format and returns a Project object which can be used to manipulate project data.

Example.Title: Retrieving Calendar Information
Example.Description: Microsoft Project lets users associate a variety of different calendars with working time, tasks and resources. These features are also available in Aspose.Tasks. This example explains how to retrieve information about which calendars are used in a project. Aspose.Tasks can retrieve calendar information for all versions of Microsoft Project: 2003, 2007, 2010, and 2013.

Example.Title: Retrieving Task Information
Example.Description: Projects are typically broken down into tasks, discreet units of work. Microsoft Project stored information about tasks, the task's name, when it will start and when it will finish. This example explains how to retrieve information for all the tasks in a project.

Example.Title: Writing Tasks to Project
Example.Description: Projects are made up by tasks. This example explains how to write tasks to a project with Aspose.Tasks for .NET.

Example.Title: Retrieving Task Links
Example.Description: Task links indicate that one task depends on another. In Microsoft Project Gantt charts, links are shown by lines that links two tasks together, or as a list of precedents. Aspose.Tasks support task links and you can use the API to add and remove task links. This article shows how to retrieve task links, essentially a list of predecessors and successors, and write them to a console window. Aspose.Tasks can retrieve Task Links information for all versions of Microsoft Project: 2003, 2007, 2010, and 2013.

Example.Title: Adding and Removing Task Links
Example.Description: Tasks are linked to show that tasks are dependent on each other. For example, task 2 cannot start until task 1 has been completed. In Microsoft Project, task links are shown as lines that connect links in a Gantt chart, or as a list of predecessors. Aspose.Tasks fully supports task links. This article explains how to add and remove task links with Aspose.Tasks.

Example.Title: Defining Root Task
Example.Description: In Microsoft Project, the root task is the parent task of all other tasks in a project. It is central to managing tasks. Aspose.Tasks lets you define a root task in a project and work with its children.

Example.Title: Adding and Removing Resources
Example.Description: In Microsoft Project, resources are the staff and equipment needed to complete a task. Aspose.Tasks lets you work with resources from within your own applications. This article explains how to add and remove resources from a project file.

Example.Title: Writing Resources to Project
Example.Description: In Microsoft Project, resources are the staff or equipment needed to complete a task. Aspose.Tasks has many features that lets you work with resources. This article focuses on how to write resources to a project.

Folder.Title: Currency Properties
Folder.Description:
Microsoft Project lets users set which currency costs are shown in, in a project. They can define set the currency code, numbers after the decimal point and currency symbol so that costs show in an easy to read and intuitive way. Aspose.Tasks supports these features and provides a series of properties that help developers set and control currency properties.
This section include the following examples:
1: Read Currency Properties 2: Set Currecncy Properties

Example.Title: Reading Currency Properties
Example.Description: The example explains how to read a project's currency properties using Aspose.Tasks

Example.Title: Set Currency Properties
Example.Description: The example explains how to set currency properties using Aspose.Tasks

Folder.Title: General Project Properties
Folder.Description:
This section includes the following topics:
- Reading Project Information - Writing Project Information

Example.Title: Reading Project Information
Example.Description: In this example, we will see how we can read the project properties using Aspose.Tasks.

Example.Title: Writing Project Information
Example.Description: In this example, we will see how we can write the project information such as scheduling the start point, the start date, current date, status date and calendar type using Aspose.Tasks,

Folder.Title: Working with Tasks
Folder.Description:
This section includes the following examples:
1: Creating tasks 2: Reading and writing general properties 3: Tasks and calendars 4: Handling constraints on tasks 5: Actual properties 6: Managing durations 7: Calculating split task finish date 8: Managing estimated / milestone tasks 9: Handling critical / effort driven tasks 10:Outline properties of a task 11:Handling priorities 12:Stop and resume a task 13:WBS associated with a task 14:Handling variances 15:Managing task costs 16:Parent / child tasks 17:Split tasks 18:Overtimes in tasks 19:Percentages calculations 20:Extended attributes of a task 21:Calculate Duration in Different Formats 22:Read Timephased Data of a Task 23:Change Progress of a Task

Example.Title: Creating Tasks
Example.Description: A project is, essentially, made up by a number of tasks, each of which has to be completed for the project to be completed. When working with project files, adding tasks is an important activity. Tasks are often linked to other tasks, to indicate dependency, and typically have a set duration. Aspose.Project lets developers create tasks and define, at the time of creation, their name, and children or duration.

Example.Title: Adding a New Task
Example.Description: Projects are made up of tasks and resources. Once you have created a project, add tasks to it to start building up the complete project plan.

Example.Title: Managing Durations
Example.Description: Tasks take time: they have a duration. Realistic task durations help give a realistic project end date. Aspose.Tasks allows developers set task durations in projects.

Example.Title: Actual Properties
Example.Description: The actual properties are used to find out how much time or money has been sent on a task to date.

Folder.Title: Reading and Writing General Properties
Folder.Description:
Tasks can be identified by a number of general properties, such as name, ID, start and finish date. Aspose.Tasks can be used to get and set task properties when working with projects. This section includes the following examples:
1: Setting General Properties 2: Getting General Properties

Example.Title: Setting General Properties
Example.Description: The Task exposes a number of general properties. This example shows how to set some of those properties using Aspose.Tasks.

Example.Title: Getting General Properties
Example.Description: In this example we will get task's properties by traversing the children of the project's RootTask property.

Folder.Title: Tasks and Calendars
Folder.Description: It is possible to associate calendars with particular tasks in Microsoft Project. Aspose.Task supports this functionality as well. The Task class exposes the Calendar property, used to set or get the calendar associated with a task. This property accepts or returns an Aspose.Tasks.Calendar object.

Example.Title: Setting Task Calendar
Example.Description: Using Aspose.Tasks, create a standard calendar and create a task. Assign the Calendar to the task.

Example.Title: Getting Task Calendar
Example.Description: To get a task calendar, traverse the tasks in a project using Aspose.Tasks.

Folder.Title: Handling Task Constraints
Folder.Description: Task constraints are used to define a Microsoft Project project's schedule and define when tasks should be started or finished. Constraints can be flexible - start or end as soon as possible or as late as possible - or inflexible. Inflexible constraints are tied to specific dates.

Example.Title: Setting Constraints
Example.Description: In this example, we will see how to apply different constraints on tasks using Aspose.Tasks.

Example.Title: Getting Constraints
Example.Description: In this example we demonstrate how to get the constraint information of a task using Aspose.Tasks.

Folder.Title: Working with Calendars
Folder.Description:
This section includes the following examples:
- Creating a Calendar - Making a Standard Calendar - General Calendar Properties - Defining Weekdays for Calendar - Getting Working Hours On or Between Dates - Writing Updated Calendar Data to MPP

Example.Title: Creating a Calendar
Example.Description: Calendars, and other information, is used by Microsoft Project to build project schedules. With Aspose.Tasks, adding a calendar to a project is easy. The Calendar class constructors allow you to assign an ID or a calendar name to the calendar, or use the default constructor.

Example.Title: Making a Standard Calendar
Example.Description: A standard calendar provides the most common work days, work hours and holidays. By default, a standard calendar is added whenever a project is created using Microsoft Project. Aspose.Tasks has features for defining a standard calendar for a project.

Example.Title: Defining Weekdays for Calendar
Example.Description: Microsoft Project keeps track of which days are considered weekdays in a calendar so that it can calculate project end dates and so on. Aspose.Tasks allows developers to define weekdays for a calendar associated with a project.

Example.Title: Getting Working Hours On or Between Dates
Example.Description: Working hours are typically defined as a range of hours over a day, on specific days of the week. For example, 09:00 – 17:00, Monday to Friday. With Aspose.Tasks, it is possible to calculate the number of working hours that fall on a date, or between two dates. Finding out the number of working dates between two dates help project managers figure out whether there are enough hours to get work done, or if they need to find more resources to complete a task.

DocLink.DisplayName: Getting Working Hours On or Between Dates

Folder.Title: Working with Task Links
Folder.Description:
This section includes the following examples:
- Creating a task link - Defining link type - Predecessor / successor tasks - Cross project predecessors - Identify tasks through cross projects

Example.Title: Creating a task link
Example.Description:
A task link is created using the default constructor (TaskLink) which accepts three parameters:
1.The first parameter defines the predecessor Task, 2.the second parameter defines the successor Task and, finally, 3.the third parameter defines the task link type from values specified by the TaskLinkType enumeration type.

Example.Title: Defining link type
Example.Description: The LinkType property exposed by the TaskLink class is used to retrieve or define the type of link between two tasks. It reads and writes one of the values defined by the TaskLinkType enumeration type.

Example.Title: Predecessor and successor tasks
Example.Description: The PredTask and SuccTask properties exposed by the TaskLink class are used to define the predecessor and successor tasks for a TaskLink. Both of these properties read and write a Task object.

Example.Title: Cross Project Predecessors
Example.Description: Microsoft Project lets users link tasks within the current project, or to external projects. Cross project predecessors are predecessors from another project. Aspose.Tasks support these too.

Example.Title: Identify Cross-Project Tasks
Example.Description: In this example, we will see that how to find the original and external ID of a task using Aspose.Tasks.

Folder.Title: Working With Task Baselines
Folder.Description:
This section includes the following topics:
- Creating a Task Baseline - Task Baseline Duration - Baseline Task Scheduling

Example.Title: Creating A Task Baseline
Example.Description: In this example, we will see how to create a task baseline using Aspose.Tasks.

Example.Title: Task Baseline Duration
Example.Description: In this example, we will see that how we can get task baseline duration using Aspose.Tasks

Example.Title: Baseline Task Scheduling
Example.Description: In this example, we will see that how we can get task baseline schedule using Aspose.Tasks.

Folder.Title: Working With Resources
Folder.Description:
This section includes the following topics:
- Creating Resources - Reading and Writing General Resource Properties - Resource and Calendars - Overtimes for a Resource - Resource Cost - Percentage Calculations - Extended Resource Attributes - Read Timephased Data of a Resource - Writing Updated Resource Data Back to MPP - Rendering Resource Usage View - Rendering Resource Sheet View

Example.Title: Overtimes For A Resource
Example.Description: In this example, we will see how we can get the resource overtimes using Aspose.Tasks.

Example.Title: Resource Cost
Example.Description: In this example, we will see how we can get the resource costs using Aspose.Tasks.

Example.Title: Percentage Calculations
Example.Description: In this example, we will see how we can calculate percentage of the work across all assignments a resource has completed using Aspose.Tasks.

Example.Title: Writing Updated Resource Data Back To MPP
Example.Description: In this example, we will see how we can update a Microsoft Project MPP file's resource data and save it data back to the MPP file using Aspose.Tasks.

DocLink.DisplayName: Writing Updated Resource Data Back to MPP

Example.Title: Read Timephased Data Of A Resource
Example.Description: In this example, we will see how we can read a resource's timephased data from Microsoft Project (MPP) files using Aspose.Tasks.

DocLink.DisplayName: Read Timephased Data of a Resource

Example.Title: Extended Resource Attributes
Example.Description: In this example, we will see how we can set a resource's extended attributes using Aspose.Tasks.

Example.Title: Rendering Resource Usage View
Example.Description: Being able to render individual project views, for example resource usage against tasks, is a common requirement for developer who work with Microsoft Project files. Aspose.Tasks supports this requirements and lets you render project resources to various formats, for example PDF. Resource usage can be rendered using Aspose.Tasks' PresentationFormat with different timescale settings like Days, ThirdofMonths and Months.

Example.Title: Rendering Resource Sheet View
Example.Description: Microsoft Project's Resource Sheet view provides details about all a project's resources. Resource information such as name, type, standard and overtime rates, costs, and calendar can be viewed using this view. Aspose.Tasks supports rendering the Resource Sheet to PDF using the PresentationFormat enumerator.

Folder.Title: Creating Resources
Folder.Description:
This section includes the following topics:
- Default Constructor - Create a Named Resource

Example.Title: Default Constructor
Example.Description: In this example, we will see how we can use the default constructor to create a resource using Aspose.Tasks.

Example.Title: Create A Named Resource
Example.Description: In this example, we will see how we can create the named resource using Aspose.Tasks.

Folder.Title: Reading And Writing General Resource Properties
Folder.Description:
This section includes the following topics:
- Setting General Resource Properties using Aspose.Tasks - Accessing General Resource Properties using Aspose.Tasks

Example.Title: Setting General Resource Properties Using Aspose.Tasks

- Setting Resource Calendar using Aspose.Tasks - Getting Resource Calendar using Aspose.Tasks

Example.Description: In this example, we will see how we can set the resorce calendar using Aspose.Tasks.

Example.Title: Getting Resource Calendar using Aspose.Tasks

Folder.Title: Working with Resource Assignments

This section includes the following examples:
- Creating Resource Assignments - General Resource Assignment Properties - Managing Assignment Cost - Assignment Budget - Handling Overtime, Remaining Costs and Work - Calculating Percentages - Dealing Variances - Stop or Resume an Assignment - Timephased Data Generation for Different Work Contours - Saving Updated Resource Assignment to MPP

Example.Title: Creating Resource Assignments
Example.Description: Resource assignments links a task and a resource. In this example, we will see how we can create resource assignments using Aspose.Tasks.

Example.Title: Managing Assignment Cost
Example.Description: In this example, we will see how we can get the cost of the task using Aspose.Tasks.

Example.Title: Assignment Budget
Example.Description: In this example, we will see how we can get the assignment budget using Aspose.Tasks.

Example.Title: Handling Overtime, Remaining Costs And Work
Example.Description: In this example, we will see how we can get assignment overtimes, remaining costs and work using Aspose.Tasks.

DocLink.DisplayName: Handling Overtime, Remaining Costs and Work

Example.Title: Calculating Percentages
Example.Description: In this example, we will see how we can get the percentage of work completed on an assignment using Aspose.Tasks.

Example.Title: Dealing Variances
Example.Description: In this example, we will see how to get the resource work variance using Aspose.Tasks.

Example.Title: Stop Or Resume An Assignment
Example.Description: In this example, we will see how we can stop or resume an assignment using Aspose.Tasks.

Example.Title: Timephased Data Generation For Different Work Contours
Example.Description: In this example, we will see how to generate timephased data for different work contours of an assigned resource using Aspose.Tasks,.

DocLink.DisplayName: Timephased Data Generation for Different Work Contours

Example.Title: Saving Updated Resource Assignment To MPP
Example.Description: In this example, we will see how to update resource assignment data and write it back to a MPP file using Aspose.Tasks.

DocLink.DisplayName: Saving Updated Resource Assignment to MPP

Folder.Title: General Resource Assignment Properties
Folder.Description:
An assignment is a resource that has been assigned to a specific task. Each resource has general properties, typically a unique ID, a start and a finish time. This section includes the following topics:
- Setting General Resource Assignment Properties using Aspose.Tasks - Getting General Resource Assignment Properties using Aspose.Tasks

Example.Title: Setting General Resource Assignment Properties
Example.Description: In this example, we will see how we can set the resource assignment properties from scratch using Aspose.Tasks.

DocLink.DisplayName: Setting General Resource Assignment Properties using Aspose.Tasks

Example.Title: Getting General Resource Assignment Properties
Example.Description: In this example, we will see how we can get the resource assignment properties using Aspose.Tasks.

DocLink.DisplayName: Getting General Resource Assignment Properties using Aspose.Tasks

Folder.Description:
This section includes the following topics:
- Managing currency codes
- Managing currency digits
- Managing currency symbols

Example.Description: In this example, we will see how we can set the currency codes using Aspose.Tasks.

Example.Title: Getting Currency
Example.Description: In this example, we will see how we can get the currency properties using Aspose.Tasks.

Folder.Title: Managing Currency Digits
Folder.Description:
Currency digits set the number of decimal points (digits after a decimal point) used for currency. This section includes the following topic:
- Setting Currency Digits using Aspose.Tasks - Getting Currency Digits using Aspose.Tasks

Example.Title: Setting Currency Digits
Example.Description: In this example, we will see how we can set the currency digits with Aspose.Tasks.

Example.Title: Getting Currency Symbol

Example.Title: Sorting Resources By Name
Example.Description: In this example, we will see how we can sort the resources by name using Aspose.Tasks.

Example.Title: Handling Exceptions
Example.Description: In this example, we will see how we can identify the cause of the exception using Aspose.Tasks.

Example.Title: Sorting Tasks By Name
Example.Description: In this example, we will see how we can sort the tasks by name using Aspose.Tasks

Example.Title: Writing Updated Outline Code Definitions And Values To MPP

DocLink.DisplayName: Writing Updated Outline Code Definitions and Values to MPP

Example.Title: Writing Metadata To MPP
Example.Description: In this example, we will see how we can write metadata to MPP files for calendars, tasks, task links, resources and resource assignments using Aspose.Tasks

Example.Description: In this example, we will see how we can render the project data to an XAML file using Aspose.Tasks.
